settings.text: Natalie Salmon is Harper’s Bazaar’s Social Media Editor and founder of website themodems.com – a hub for her latest discoveries and recommendations in the world of technology. We caught up with Natalie to talk lockdown dressing, must-have apps and the joys of online shopping.

settings.grid-content:
As Harper’s Bazaar’s social media editor, how has working from home changed your day to day role?

As my role is mainly digital, I haven’t had to change things that much although now all our meetings are happening over Zoom. I thought working from home would give me lots of spare time, but I feel like I have been busier than ever.

How would you describe your working from home style?

My style is always evolving – but I would generally describe it as polished classics with a twist.

At the moment I’m in nesting mode so have been wearing lots of cosy knits, tracksuits and leggings. You can’t go wrong with soft cashmere and chic loungewear.

settings.text:
Whose personal style inspires you?

I have so many vintage references I keep looking back to which totally influence my style; Lee Radziwill, Marchesa Luisa Casati, and Bianca Jagger among them. I also love current French style icons, Caroline de Maigret and Carine Roitfeld.

How are you spending your extra free time around the house?

I did a calligraphy course a couple of years ago and have really gotten back into it, I thought it would be a totally useless skill but there is something quite soothing about it. I bought a book called Calm Calligraphy and practice from that whenever I have a break from work.

settings.grid-content:
What inspired you to start your website themodems.com?

I wanted a place to put all the information I’d learned about social media and share all of the tech updates for women that never get much coverage - for instance, chic smart watches and stories such as women using VR headsets during pregnancy.

Has technology changed the way you shop?

Absolutely, I shop online more than ever before and love the edits on sites such as Net-A-Porter. I also love that apps like Oprent and By Rotation have made it possible to borrow outfits for special occasions.

What do you think the future holds for fashion and technology?

I think the future is really exciting, there is so much happening with digital clothing offerings and VR where you will be able to try items on virtually – for instance, pointing your mobile phone at your feet to try on sneakers, or using your front camera to try on makeup before you buy it. A few brands already do this and it’s gaining a lot of traction in the US, I think it’s going to change the way we shop.

settings.title: Natalie Recommends...
settings.text:
The one gadget you can’t live without?

My Series 5 Apple watch

Home workout of choice?

The 7 Minute Workout app and online Bodyism classes.

Favourite shopping app?

I was devastated when Polyvore shut down as that was my favourite. I love the Etsy app for finding unique and vintage items.

Favourite way of staying in touch with friends and family?

Houseparty app


Apps just for fun?

I would recommend trying Drest, a mobile fashion game where you get to play virtual stylist and Pret-a-Template, an app you can use to draw fashion sketches.
